questions.question: Identify the structures labeled A and B:

choices.answer: A: Type I pneumocytes; B: Type II pneumocytes
A: Type II pneumocytes; B: Type I pneumocytes
A: Capillaries; B: Type I pneumocytes
A: Capillaries; B: Type II pneumocytes

choices.answer: The affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen is increased
The affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen is decreased

questions.question: When oxygen binds to hemoglobin in the blood, it causes a shape change meaning that:
The oxygen dissociation curve for hemoglobin shows that:

choices.answer: At low pO<sub>2</sub>, most heme groups are carrying oxygen
At higher pO<sub>2</sub> affinity for O<sub>2</sub> increases
As pO<sub>2</sub> increases percent saturation with O<sub>2</sub> decreases
Hemoglobin becomes saturated with O<sub>2</sub> at very high pO<sub>2</sub>.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the point A marked by the arrow?

choices.answer: This represents conditions in the body tissues.
This represents conditions in lungs.
O<sub>2</sub> is rapidly dissociating from hemoglobin
Hemoglobin's affinity for O<sub>2</sub> is high
It has a higher affinity for O<sub>2</sub> than adult hemoglobin
It has a lower affinity for O<sub>2</sub> than adult hemoglobin

questions.question: Fetal hemoglobin is different from adult hemoglobin because:

choices.answer: Only carried in solution
Only bound to hemoglobin in the blood
Both carried in solution + bound to hemoglobin in the blood

questions.question: Carbon dioxide is transported by being:

imageMetadata.resources: By OpenStax College [CC BY 3.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0)], via Wikimedia Commons CC3.0

questions.resources: By OpenStax College [CC BY 3.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0)], via Wikimedia Commons CC3.0

choices.answer: H<sup>+ </sup>which then creates carbonic acid and HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>- </sup>
HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>- </sup>which then dissociates into carbonic acid and H<sup>+</sup>
HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>- </sup>which then creates carbonic acid and H<sup>+</sup>
Carbonic acid which then dissociates into HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> and H<sup>+</sup>

questions.question: In red blood cells (erythrocytes), CO<sub>2</sub> forms:
H<sup>+</sup> ions left over increase the acidity (decrease pH) of the blood. Which statement is true:

choices.answer: Blood pH is ‘buffered’ to stay between 7.45 - 7.85
Blood pH is ‘buffered’ to stay at 7.35
Blood pH is ‘buffered’ to stay between 7.35 - 7.45
Blood pH is varies widely but is mainly between 7.35 - 7.45

questions.question: The Bohr shift shows how at a given pO<sub>2</sub>, hemoglobin's affinity for O<sub>2</sub> is:

choices.answer: Increased where pCO<sub>2</sub> is high (e.g. in respiring cells)
Reduced where pCO<sub>2</sub> is high (e.g. in respiring cells)
Does not change despite changing pCO<sub>2</sub>
Chemoreceptors in the vena cava and carotid arteries
Thermoreceptors in the aorta and carotid arteries
Thermoreceptors in the vena cava and carotid arteries
Chemoreceptors in the aorta and carotid arteries

questions.question: Decreased blood pH due to increased CO<sub>2</sub> from respiration is detected by:

choices.answer: Actions potentials sent from the cerebellum
Hormones sent produced by the medulla oblongata
Actions potentials sent from the medulla oblongata
Hormones sent produced by the cerebellum

questions.question: The rate of ventilation is controlled by:

choices.answer: The concentration of CO<sub>2</sub> in the blood
An increase in heart rate
The concentration of O<sub>2</sub> in the blood
A decrease in heart rate
